Name: Linear Programming
Description: An optimization problem where the objective function and all constraints are linear functions of the decision variables. Variables are continuous.
Solvability: Efficiently solvable to a global optimum in polynomial time (e.g., using Interior-Point methods) or via the Simplex algorithm.
Example: The Diet Problem (finding the cheapest combination of foods to meet nutritional requirements), Resource Allocation.

Name: Mixed-Integer Linear Programming
Description: A type of LP where some, but not all, decision variables are restricted to be integers. This allows for modeling logical choices (e.g., yes/no decisions).
Solvability: NP-hard in general. Solved using methods like Branch and Bound. Practical solvability depends heavily on problem size and structure.
Example: Facility Location, Supply Chain Network Design, Unit Commitment in power generation.

Name: Nonlinear Programming
Description: An optimization problem where the objective function or at least one of the constraints is a nonlinear function of the decision variables.
Solvability: Can be very difficult. If convex, a global optimum can be found efficiently. If non-convex, solvers may only find a local optimum. Finding the global optimum is generally NP-hard.
Example: Training a deep neural network, Shape optimization in engineering.

Name: Quadratic Programming
Description: A type of NLP where the objective function is a quadratic function and the constraints are linear.
Solvability: If the objective function is convex, the problem is efficiently solvable. If non-convex, it is much harder (NP-hard).
Example: Markowitz portfolio optimization in finance, Support Vector Machines (SVM) in machine learning.

Name: Convex Optimization
Description: A broad class of problems (including LP and convex QP) where the objective is a convex function and the feasible set is a convex set. A key property is that any local minimum is also a global minimum.
Solvability: Efficiently solvable to a global optimum. This class has well-developed theory and powerful solvers.
Example: LASSO regression, Geometric programming, many machine learning problems.

Name: Combinatorial Optimization
Description: A field concerned with finding an optimal object from a finite set of objects. Problems are typically discrete and often involve graphs.
Solvability: Many prominent problems are NP-hard, requiring heuristics, approximation algorithms, or integer programming formulations to solve for large instances.
Example: Traveling Salesperson Problem (TSP), Vehicle Routing Problem (VRP).

Name: Integer Linear Programming
Description: A type of LP where all decision variables are restricted to be integers. A special case of MILP.
Solvability: NP-hard in general. It is at least as hard as MILP.
Example: The Knapsack Problem, Set Covering Problem, Sudoku.

Name: Stochastic Programming
Description: Optimization problems that involve uncertainty, where some of the parameters are represented by probability distributions.
Solvability: Computationally very intensive. Often solved by formulating large-scale deterministic equivalents or using sampling-based methods.
Example: Financial planning under uncertain market conditions, optimal operation of a dam with uncertain rainfall.

Name: Dynamic Programming
Description: A method for solving complex problems by breaking them down into a collection of simpler, nested subproblems. It's used for sequential decision-making over time.
Solvability: Solvability depends on the state space and problem structure. Can suffer from the 'curse of dimensionality' where the state space grows exponentially.
Example: Shortest path problems in a graph (Bellman-Ford algorithm), Inventory Control.

Name: Robust Optimization
Description: A branch of optimization that deals with uncertainty by optimizing for the worst-case scenario within a given uncertainty set. It provides solutions that are feasible for any realization of the uncertainty.
Solvability: Often results in a computationally tractable problem (e.g., LP, SOCP), but can be more conservative than stochastic programming.
Example: Designing a bridge to withstand the worst-case load, robust portfolio management.
